body.head: Die letzten fünf Sonaten von Beethoven (Erläuterungsausgabe)

div.p: Schenker's edition of four of the last five piano sonatas of Beethoven, published separately, and based in each case on surviving autograph manuscript and sketch materials, and early editions, and drawing on Nottebohm's publications and private notes. This edition is in each case accompanied by Schenker's elucidations (Erläuterungen), which describe the sources, analyze structure and thematic content (with copious music examples, and in the case of Op. 101 Urlinien), provide detailed guidelines for performance, and encompass a survey of the previous secondary literature and editions. The four volumes were published by Universal Edition of Vienna between 1913 and 1921.

The motivation for this edition was to discredit the 19th-century editions, not only of these works but of those of the German and Austrian classical composers in general, against which Schenker had for many years polemicized; to show that with the exception of fingerings little or no editorial intervention was usually required — i.e. that Beethoven's orthography, when correctly understood and explained, provided all that was needed for understanding a work's structure and performing it according to his wishes; and ultimately to reveal the processes of mind of a supreme "master" of musical composition — to uncover the workings of genius.

Because these volumes were prepared for the most part during World War I, they served also as a principal vehicle for Schenker's German nationalist feelings, and his intense antipathy toward the nations of the West, and this polemical stratum of the work relates directly to the leading article "Von der Sendung des deutschen Genies," in the first issue of Der Tonwille (1921), and his Preface to Kontrapunkt 2 (1922).

The five volumes of the work, which were to have been published one per year (contract: OC 52/494, August 25, 1912) but for the impact of the war upon both Schenker's research and the commerce of publishing, were:
Die letzten fünf Sonaten von Beethoven ... op. 109 (1913)
Die letzten fünf Sonaten von Beethoven ... op. 110 (1914)
Die letzten fünf Sonaten von Beethoven ... op. 111 (1916)
Die letzten fünf Sonaten von Beethoven ... op. 101 (1921)
Die letzten fünf Sonaten von Beethoven ... op. 106 (unpublished)

div.head: New Edition
div.p: A new edition was produced in four separate, smaller-format volumes in 1971–72 by Oswald Jonas, pupil of Schenker and Hans Weisse. Jonas excised from Schenker's original all the polemical material and the entire discussion of the secondary literature, and also replaced Schenker's editions of the sonatas by Erwin Ratz's edition of 1945 with the effect that the scores contradict some of the textual argument in Schenker's elucidations.

div.head: English Translation and Study
div.p: An English translation of all four published volumes of the Erläuterungsausgabe by John Rothgeb is currently in progress (2010). A new study of Op. 106 ("Hammerklavier") by Nicholas Marston, amplifying Schenker's unpublished work on the sonata (in the Oster Collection, OC 65), is also in preparation.
